text: I think that the idea of reading from a
universal point of view is a fantasy. Uh
you read from your own point of view,
from a particular place in time, uh from
who you are and what your interests are.
Maybe we will if when we become cyborgs
of some kind or other and cease to have
uh any fleshly existence. But as far as
I know now, even in our current
situation, uh we read from the
particular people we are and with the
particular interests we have. So
whatever we mean by universality in art,
Shakespearean or otherwise, I think
doesn't have to do with a liftoff that
lets you escape everything, the time and
place it was produced and the time and
place you're produced. That said, the
key question is how is it possible for a
work that was written in a particular
circumstance with a particular set of
interests nonetheless to speak to other
people across uh a huge gap in time. I
remember as a freshman in college
reading
Chaucer wrote in the 14th century and
thinking really they had irony back
then? uh being amazed that I could hear
this voice, this laughing ironic voice
that sounded like it was uh my
contemporary though I also understood
that it wasn't my contemporary. It was
written from the 14th century. Uh one
feels that in Homer, one feels that in
Shakespeare, one feels that in lots of
texts that come from very far away. If
you take um what would be an example? um
a poem by Thomas Wyatt writing at the
time of Henry VIII. Wyatt was probably
the lover of Anne Berlin. He finds
himself in in kind of erotic agony
because his mistress has been taken from
him and he sits down to write a poem.
They flee from me that sometime did me
seek with naked foot stalking in my
chamber. I have seen them gentle, tame,
and meek that now are wild, and do not
put themselves, and do not remember that
sometime they put themselves in danger
to take bread at my hand. And now they
range busily seeking with a continual
chain. But once in special, in thin
array after a pleasant guise, when her
loose gown from her shoulders did fall,
and she me caught in her arms long and
small, there with all sweetly did me
kiss, and softly said, "Dear heart, how
like you this." The poem goes on, but
we'll stop for a moment
there. We have a very particular memory.
once in special one special time in thin
array after a pleasant guy is an erotic
memory that he's had presumably about
something in his life from the early
16th
century it's a very special context this
context of the Henriian court of Anne
Bolin of Thomas Wyatt if the poem
works as it does for me it works because
it somehow is making connection to me
across this huge gap of time and class
and culture and identity. I can't
explain fully why. I mean, I could try
to account psychoanalytically for why it
might have some connection, though I'm
not inclined to do it at the moment. Uh,
but it has to do with the language. It
has to do with the kind of incantatory
magic of words. It has to do with what
happens to the air as it passes through
your lungs as you recite the verses. it
has some connection to uh to love and
disappointment and it crosses barriers
and that's what is the fascination of
works of art but it doesn't mean that
it's universal. It doesn't mean that it
escapes from time and place. It means
that it's able to be mobile and mobility
rather than universality is really for
me the key issue.
